priorVersion.title: CDISC SDTM Trial Summary Parameter Short Name Terminology

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C66738

self.title: CDISC SDTM Trial Summary Parameter Short Name Terminology

definition: The test code for an individual characteristic of a clinical trial, e.g. description of trial design, trial blinding schema, and primary objective of trial.
name: Trial Summary Parameter Test Code
preferredTerm: CDISC SDTM Trial Summary Parameter Short Name Terminology

terms.definition: Actual number of subjects enrolled; may include subjects who were not randomized.

Indicate if the study includes a prospectively planned opportunity for modification of one or more specified aspects of the study design and hypotheses based on analysis of data (usually interim data) from subjects in the study.
The addition of a therapeutic product to the existing regimen in a clinical trial, where both entities remain as discrete products.
terms.preferredTerm: Test Product Added to Existing Treatment

terms.definition: The anticipated maximum age of the subjects to be entered in a clinical trial. (NCI)
The anticipated minimum age of the subjects to be entered in a clinical trial. (NCI)
A textual description as to whether a biospecimen is retained and/or contains DNA.
terms.preferredTerm: Biospecimen Retained and/or Contains DNA Indicator

terms.definition: A bibliographical reference related to a particular study.
The state or condition of the sponsor as pertains to whether the sponsor is considered a commercial entity.
A therapeutically active agent that is intended to provide reference measurements for the experimental protocol of a clinical trial.
E-mail address of study contact.
Mailing address of study contact.
Name of study contact.
Phone number of study contact.
Role of study contact.
The protocol specified minimum amount of time needed to meet the definition of a confirmed response to treatment.
The date when the clinical study report was archived.
The name and version of the CDISC therapeutic area user guide that is being used in the study submission.
terms.preferredTerm: CDISC Therapeutic Area User Guide Name and Version

terms.definition: The literal identifier of the therapy or medication that is currently being given per protocol.
Text that describes the cutoff date.
A date which indicates any data collected by this date will be used for analysis.
A standard by which the determination of delayed graft function (DGF) is established.
terms.preferredTerm: Delayed Graft Function Diagnostic Criteria Name

terms.definition: An indication as to whether the clinical trial has an appointed data monitoring committee.
The amount of study drug (or placebo) administered to a patient or test subject to be taken at one time or at stated intervals.
The physical form in which active and/or inert ingredient(s) are presented.
The number of doses administered per a specific interval.
The planned schedule for the administration of an agent (such as a drug, substance or radiation).
The unit of measure for the dosage form.
A standard from which a judgment concerning a medical diagnosis can be established.
Indicates whether assessors of ECGs for this study were blinded to subject identity, timing and treatment.
Indicates whether the 10-second ECGs for this study were extracted from a continuous recording.
The ECG lead which was planned to be used for ECG interval measurements for this study.
terms.preferredTerm: ECG Planned Primary Lead for Study

terms.definition: Indicates whether all ECG interval measurements for the study were based on the same lead.
The degree of automation involved in assessing the ECGs for this study.
terms.preferredTerm: ECG Read Method Degree of Automation

terms.definition: Indicates whether this study includes replicate ECGs for time points during the baseline portion of the study.
Indicates whether this study includes replicate ECGs for time points during the on-treatment portion of the study.
The algorithm used to identify the end of the T wave for ECGs for this study.
The Email address to which copies of the XML format of the EudraCT application should be sent.
terms.preferredTerm: E-mail Address for XML File Feedback

terms.definition: An alphanumeric code assigned by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) to an EMA regulatory decision for a pediatric investigation plan (PIP).
terms.preferredTerm: EMA Decision Number for Pediatric Investigation Plan

terms.definition: An indication as to whether the study disruption was caused by the epidemic or pandemic.
terms.preferredTerm: Epidemic or Pandemic Related Disruption Indicator

terms.definition: The literal identifier of the epidemic and/or pandemic.
An indication as to whether the trial being submitted to the EudraCT is a trial that has been previously submitted to the EudraCT system.
A unique identifier assigned to the organization that is transmitting an adverse drug reaction report to the EudraVigilance system.
The name of the group or institution that is transmitting an adverse drug reaction report to the EudraVigilance system.
The unique alphanumeric identifier for the study with associated expanded access record, as assigned by the clinicaltrials.gov protocol registration and results system (PRS).
terms.preferredTerm: Clinicaltrials.gov NCT Number for the Expanded Access Record

terms.definition: Status indicating availability of an experimental drug or device outside any clinical trial protocol. (clinicaltrials.gov)
An indication as to whether the clinical trial is an extension trial.
The country name of planned study facility which has received IRB approval.
An indication as to whether the study involves an FDA-regulated device.
An indication as to whether the study involves an FDA-regulated drug.
The name and version of the FDA technical specification that is being used in the study submission.
terms.preferredTerm: FDA Technical Specification Name and Version

terms.definition: Indicate if persons who have not had the condition(s) being studied or otherwise related conditions or symptoms, as specified in the eligibility requirements, may participate in the study.
The textual representation of the condition, disease or disorder that the clinical trial is intended to investigate or address.
The general design of the strategy for assigning interventions to participants in a clinical study. (clinicaltrials.gov)
The kind of product or procedure studied in a trial.
A word or small set of words designed to convey the focus of the protocol.
Planned length of observation for a single subject.
The name of the country within which the final product under study is produced.
An indication as to whether the clinical study is being conducted at multiple sites within the European Union member state concerned by the application.
terms.preferredTerm: Multiple Site European Union State Trial Indicator
synonyms: Multiple Site EU State Trial Indicator

terms.definition: The planned number of intervention groups.
The number of groups or cohorts that are part of the study.
The total number of trial sites within the European Union member state concerned by the application.
terms.preferredTerm: Number of Trial Sites within European Union State
synonyms: Number of Trial Sites EU State

terms.definition: The exploratory purpose of the trial.
A principle objective of the study.
An auxiliary objective of the study.
The trial design developed to compare biomedical and/or health outcomes in pre-defined and non-assigned groups of individuals.
The temporal relationship between the observation period and time of subject enrollment. (ClinicalTrials.gov)
A description of the population from which the groups or cohorts will be selected within an observational study.
The sampling method used to assign study participants into groups or cohorts within an observational study.
A textual description of the sampling method used to assign study participants into groups or cohorts within an observational study.

Additional key measures that will be used to evaluate the intervention(s) or, for observational studies, that are a focus of the study. These are the outcome measures not used to assess primary or secondary objectives.

The outcome measure(s) that is part of a pre-specified analysis plan used to evaluate the exploratory endpoint(s) associated with exploratory study objective(s) and/or any other measures, excluding post-hoc measures, that are a focus of the study. (After clinicaltrials.gov)

The outcome measure(s) of greatest importance specified in the protocol, usually the one(s) used in the power calculation, to evaluate the primary endpoint(s) associated with the primary study objective(s). (After Clinicaltrials.gov)

The outcome measure(s) that is part of a pre-specified analysis plan used to evaluate the secondary endpoint(s) associated with secondary study objective(s) and/or used to evaluate any measure(s) ancillary to the primary or secondary endpoint(s). (After Clinicaltrials.gov).
An indication as to whether the clinical study is a post authorization safety study.
The pharmacological class of the investigational product.
An indication as to whether the study is a pediatric postmarket study.
An indication as to whether the study is a pediatric study.
An indication as to whether the trial is part of a pediatric investigation plan (PIP).
The planned number of subjects to be entered in a clinical trial. (NCI)
The approximate period of time over which the clinical trial is expected to occur.
The potential future harm that may arise from a protocol-related activity.
The period of time during which the treatment is intended to be given.
A globally unique identifier for a biomedical article, as assigned by PubMed.
synonyms: PubMed ID for Citation Used in Study

terms.definition: The process of assigning trial subjects to treatment or control groups using an element of chance to determine the assignments in order to reduce bias. NOTE: Unequal randomization is used to allocate subjects into groups at a differential rate; for example, three subjects may be assigned to a treatment group for every one assigned to the control group. [ICH E6 1.48] See also balanced study. (CDISC glossary)
The randomization quotient is the number of planned subjects to be exposed to investigational therapy, independent of dose or other factors, divided by the total number of planned subjects.
An indication as to whether the condition under study is considered a rare disease.
Identification numbers assigned to the protocol by clinicaltrials.gov, EudraCT, or other registries.
An alphabetic character that describes the incremental order of trial resubmissions.
A standard from which a judgment concerning a disease relapse can be established.
The pathway by which a substance is administered in order to reach the site of action in the body.
A textual description of the specimen types that are retained as reserve samples.
An indication as to whether the registrant would like to receive an XML copy of their study as saved on EudraCT.
synonyms: Request for XML Copy of Study Indicator

terms.definition: The protocol specified minimum amount of time needed to meet the definition of stable disease.
The version of the CDISC Study Data Tabulation Model implementation guide that is being used in the study submission.
terms.preferredTerm: Study Data Tabulation Model Implementation Guide Version

terms.definition: The version of the CDISC Study Data Tabulation Model implementation guide for medical devices that is being used in the study submission.
terms.preferredTerm: SDTM Implementation Guide Medical Device Version
synonyms: SDTM Implementation Guide Medical Device Version

terms.definition: The version of the CDISC Study Data Tabulation Model that is being used in the study submission.
An indication as to whether the XML copy of the EudraCT application requires secure E-mail delivery.
terms.preferredTerm: Requires Secure Email Delivery of XML Indicator

terms.definition: The date on which the final data item for a clinical study was collected from the last study participant (that is, last subject, last visit, or as otherwise defined in the study protocol). (CDISC Glossary)
A standard from which a judgment concerning the severity of an event, disease or condition can be established.
The specific sex, either male, female, or mixed of the subject group being studied. (NCI)

An individual, company, institution, or organization that takes responsibility for the initiation, management, and/or financing of a clinical study. [After ICH E6, WHO, 21 CFR 50.3 (e), and after IDMP]

The reference identifier by which the study is known to the sponsor. This may be different from the STUDYID if the data were collected under a different identifier (e.g., used in a situation where a contract facility performs the study and provides a final report).
An indication as to whether suspected unexpected serious adverse reactions (SUSAR) will be reported to a EudraVigiliance clinical trial module (EVCTM).
terms.preferredTerm: SUSAR Reporting to EudraVigiliance Clinical Trial Module Indicator

terms.definition: An indication as to whether suspected unexpected serious adverse reactions (SUSAR) will be reported to national competent authorities (NCA).
terms.preferredTerm: SUSAR Reporting to National Competent Authority Indicator

terms.definition: An indication as to whether the clinical study is being conducted at only one site within the European Union member state concerned by the application.
terms.preferredTerm: Single Site European Union State Trial Indicator
synonyms: Single Site EU State Trial Indicator

terms.definition: The earliest date of informed consent among any subject (Date/Time of Informed Consent, RFICDTC) that enrolled in the study. For studies conducted without informed consent (ie. emergency use) use the date of treatment. Dates for subjects who were screen failures are not included.
A textual description of the substudy.
An indication as to whether a study performed on a subgroup of subjects included in the original trial (substudy) is planned for the current study.
The rule, regulation and/or condition that determines the point in time when a clinical trial will be terminated. (NCI)

Selected factors that are used during randomization to ensure there is balance of these factors across all subjects within each arm of a study. The subject level values of these factors may be used as fixed effects in statistical models and for sensitivity analyses.
The nature of the investigation for which study information is being collected. (After clinicaltrials.gov)

The type of experimental design used to describe the level of awareness of the study subjects and/ or study personnel as it relates to the respective intervention(s) or assessments being observed, received or administered.
Comparator against which the study treatment is evaluated.
A grouping of individuals on the basis of a shared procedure or disease, or lack thereof.

A categorization of a disease, disorder, or other condition based on common characteristics and often associated with a medical specialty focusing on research and development of specific therapeutic interventions for the purpose of treatment and prevention.
The planned purpose of the therapy, device, or agent under study in the clinical trial.
The sponsor-defined name of the clinical study.

A step in the clinical research and development of a therapy from initial clinical trials to post-approval studies. NOTE: Clinical trials are generally categorized into four (sometimes five) phases. A therapeutic intervention may be evaluated in two or more phases simultaneously in different trials, and some trials may overlap two different phases. [21 CFR section 312.21; After ICH Topic E8 NOTE FOR GUIDANCE ON GENERAL CONSIDERATIONS FOR CLINICAL TRIALS, CPMP/ICH/291/95 March 1998]
The anticipated time period over which each study participant is to be followed. (ClinicalTrials.gov)
The investigational product under study.
The nature of the interventional study for which information is being collected.
The uniform resource locator (URL) related to a particular study.
A textual description of the uniform resource locator (URL) related to a particular study.
terms.preferredTerm: Study Protocol Uniform Resource Locator Description
